author: eagle
title: Get PAYDA
description: Sending funds is sometimes scary. It involves copy/pasting addresses or manually sending addresses for others to type in on websites.

f6_assessments.q0: Get PAYDA is a proposal to bring in new functionality to the getpayda.com website that currently allows people to create invoices for people to pay someones ADA address. The proposal seeks to integrate additional wallets, direct payments and improve the user experience in this proposal. This solutions provides a simple way for someone to create an invoice for other people when they are expecting payment rather than send all of these details manually to another person or organisation. Handling more wallets and direct payments is a suitable next step in the development of this site. Other features as some suggestions could be a payment status on the invoice and also be able to print to a well formatted PDF file to export could be nice added features in the future. The deliverables of the proposal are clear, more information on the longer term intentions for the proposal would have been useful to include and the type of users the author is looking to attract in the early term as well. This would have helped to highlight and understanding of how this could be sustainable and attain early adoption to be used in the ecosystem. In a similar light it would have been good for the proposer to outline the risks of adoption for this product and how they will approach sharing it for testing and how they try to prevent it becoming a created product that never gets any usage. Another improvement could have been example users or conversations that go through the problems people are facing and why this solution will be useful to them - is this actually a useful solution right now?
f6_assessments.q1: The progress of this proposal is broken down into three month stages which is integrating additional wallets and then integrating direct payments and the finishing off with improving the design. The proposer states they have 10 years development experience. The website provides some evidence of this however a professional link or other work being provided in the proposal would have given more confidence towards the skills of the proposer. Overall because the current implementation is already live and functioning there is at least some moderate evidence that this proposal will be feasible. This is coupled with the fact the proposal is not requesting a large amount of funds and the scope is reasonable and a logical next step.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposers intend to measure through user adoption for the progress. It would have been good to know if anything would be open source with a Github repository or for their to be details of where to find updates on any changes. There is a Twitter that is on the website - being specific that this may be where updates go would have been useful to know for instance. In terms of success the implementation of the features is listed. It would have been good to be more specific with the objectives on who they will try to focus on that may use it in the ecosystem in these early stages so that the proposer can start getting a feedback loop for future development. Because the proposal already has an executed product which can be audited and tracked for future changes and the clarity of the proposal is high albeit simple I would agree this proposal is at least somewhat auditable.

f6_assessments.q0:
Get Payda is an ADA payment solution that generates invoices sent to payers, after having connected our wallet. A working prototype is running (I tested it, and you can test it too on https://getpayda.com). 
As it currently only support Yoroi wallet, this proposal is made by EAGLE to integrate the Dapp connector from other wallets.
This proposal has a clear goal, and its purpose meets the challenge criteria ("Increased quality of existing products & integrations through suggested improvements that is supported by customer feedback or increased usage by the community.").
f6_assessments.q1:
The development plan includes support for more wallets (it would have been better to name the targetted wallets), include payment via wallets and improve UX and design of the webapp. This will be achieved along a 3 months project, for which the proposer requests $12,500. 
Although not much details are provided about the proposer (10 year of experience in developing apps), he has already developed an MVP, funded by a previous Catalyst Fund. He has have proved that he delivers.
f6_assessments.q2: This is a simple project and it has a clear and simple roadmap. Mentioning a public communication channel to let the community know about the progress update would be a good thing. But since development only lasts 3 months, tracking progress isn't a big deal.

f6_assessments.q0:
The idea of this proposal, basically, aims to facilitate the sending of funds within the cardano platform.

This, according to the proposer, because there are still difficulties/risks involved in copying the addresses or passing them manually. This process often generates doubts and is not intuitive for many people. Therefore, the solution seeks to mitigate this process, connecting users' wallets and generating invoices that can be sent and paid by the other party.

This solution aligns with the challenge because it aims to improve the usability of blockchain and this is essential for anyone looking to be number 1 in the world. It is really necessary to think of solutions that make users, whoever they are, more comfortable using blockchain.

The goals of this part of the project is the completion of all necessary functionality. However, it remains to be said how much they want and/or think they are able to achieve (impact within the blockchain).
f6_assessments.q1:
In order to verify its feasibility, we need to verify the following aspects:
1 – roadmap: The proposed roadmap consists only of macro tasks, separated by months. As a suggestion, in order to better assess the possibility of completing this project, we must add all the micro-tasks, with checkpoints, with the members who will develop each part, and also add which tools would be needed. Adding these questions would give an overview of whether or not it is possible to do, or whether the team knows the path to be taken to complete each part. In addition, it would allow the community to help them at some stage.

2 – budget: The budget has the same problems presented in the roadmap. It is very general, lacking further details on resource development and allocation. And, of course, it has the same suggestions for improvement as in the roadmap.

3 – team: The only team member presented was the main developer and, yet, no evidence of knowledge or experience was presented. As a suggestion, it is important to add all participating members, as they are essential for the development of the proposal.

4 – risk management: were presented some risks and actions to mitigate them, therefore this part seems fair.

5 – self-funding/scalability: The monetization proposal presented was to use the next funds, so that the project is increased. However, it would be interesting to think of a form of monetization. Maybe even take a minimal percentage of transactions that take place within the platform, or a membership fee.
f6_assessments.q2:
In order to audit, we need:
1 – roadmap w/ milestones: Due to the roadmap not being well designed and lacking detailing and subdivisions into smaller tasks, it is difficult to audit this proposal, mainly because intermediate checkpoints were not presented.

2 – Metrics and KPI: The metrics and KPI presented are able to verify the adoption of the platform and, with that, its development.

3 – Channel: They already have a platform in which they could share information about the development of new features.

f6_assessments.q0: The "Get PAYDA" project offers an extremely simple invoice generator via the web. Users connect their NAMI wallet and fill in optional fields like invoice recipient, comment and email to generate a weblink or QR code that can then be sent to whomever you are asking to get paid by. To a lot of experienced crypto users this may seem like very little value added, but to less tech-savvy users or those scared by wallet addresses, this is a nifty tool and adds considerable convenience over manually creating a similar link or code. To boost acceptance of payments between NAMI wallets (for example to pay a friend, collaborator or contractor you are trying to introduce to the world of Cardano / ADA monetary system) this should go a long way. Therefore, I agree that this proposal is very effective at reaching some of the goals of this challenge setting, namely total number of wallets, total number of users, drive adoption, drive growth.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal does not provide a lot of information in the form, but instead uses it's website and Twitter page to communicate what the proposal is about. There are no links, no budget breakdown, proposer profiles, timeline or milestones. The proposer provides a real name, and google searches about the proposer and project allow to "patch" together the required information. It would have been nice to receive this data in the form, as this would demonstrate commitment and respect for the funds involved. There is, however, nothing in the omission of filling the form that makes it any less likely that the project will be completed successfully, which looks highly likely based on the work already done. As the technical realization of the project should not be very difficult, and the utility is almost there, three months work will most likely be sufficient to finish the project as promised.
f6_assessments.q2: Tracking the number of payment requests is the only KPI of the project, and there are no channels apart from the existing Twitter channel how progress feedback may be shared with the community as the website currently does not have any contact or news features. This would be nice-to-have, but again are not required to fulfil the promised utility and achieve the targeted impact. The proposer mentions that future features may be offered through additional Catalyst proposals, and the Twitter page mentions a possible PAYDA coin and ISPO. To scale to this kind of utility would require a quantum leap in transparency, community interaction and sophistication. For the current stage of the project and to provide the basic need of sending ada invoices, all is good and the proposal should be auditable via its website and Twitter.

f6_assessments.q0:
This is a proposal that attempts to address a real problem common in blockchain tech (discomfort with the nature of crypto transactions and its hazards) and has presented us a prototype invoicing system for address this in GetPayda. 

Unfortunately, it ends there, rendering it barely adequate. This is a proposal that suffers badly from lack of detail. Since this is a problem endemic to the entire proposal, I'm going to use this assessment to suggest information this developer could provide that would flesh out this proposal.

- The proposer says he wishes to integrate additional wallets. Please tell us 1) how many wallets are currently integrated, 2) how many wallets you intend to integrate, 3) by when.

- The proposer wishes to clean up the user experience and design of the website. Can you describe for us, even loosely, some of the changes you wish to make? It's clear the website is pretty basic as is but you should be able to give us a sense of the work you intend to do with some description.
f6_assessments.q1:
- The proposer provides a very basic roadmap of month-by-month costs for development. Please provide a little more detail about the first two months, as you did with the third month "(design and styling)." You can also give us a sense of the amount of labor involved so we can assess your pay rate per hour, which would be a good way to enhance the transparency of the proposal.

- The proposer states that he has 10 years of experience developing mobile apps and websites. Could you provide us with examples? Even just one or two? Show us your accomplishments! 

- The proposer states that he will continue to grow this project in future rounds. What are some of the ideas involved in the long-term vision for this project? What are we, as voters, setting the stage for with this project?
f6_assessments.q2:
- The proposer states that he will measure progress through the number of users who have created a funding request. This is why we need existing numbers and goal setting. How many funding requests have been issued so far? How many do you hope to have by when? Set both an ambitious goal and a minimum goal, if you're afraid of being judged harshly in the auditing process.

And that is all. This proposal has the basics all around with no detail to add confidence to the project in its descriptions, start to finish, which is why every category is getting three stars. Everything is, basically, average.

f6_assessments.q0: People/users have expressed ambiguity when it comes to payment using/to wallet addresses. These proposal intends to address these problem by providing/building a platform where users can generate invoices which can then be sent to parties involved in the transaction/business. These will however, provide more clarity and lessen the uncertainty sorrounding making payment to manually sent addresses (Since according to the proposed design structure, Invoices will be generated by a smart contract directly in/by the wallets that is supposed to receive such payment).
f6_assessments.q1:
To begin with, the project is already an ongoing project with a working prototype that seamlessly connects with Nami and yoroi wallets and users can generate payment addresses already. Furthermore, the proposer provides an objective timeline with relevant milestones that satisfactorily explains a proper continuation of the current developed prototype, the budget and requested amount is fair and reasonable. these however confirms to me that the team can be relied upon for the execution of the idea/project (All information and links provided nicely and realistically add up). I'll suggest to the team to modify the solution such that the payment address in invoice will not be the regular alphanumeric wallet address, they should modify it to be in a simple human readable format, these will further simplify the solution.
As for the team,  the information provided is very minimal but yet, with the amount of fair and reasonable infomation provided of proof of workdone, i believe the team can deliver.
f6_assessments.q2: The metrics and KPIs provided is sufficient to track progress and evaluate success. These includes major milestones as they are met within the stipulated timeframe (support for more wallets, payment via wallets, better UI/UX design) as mentioned in the proposal. Also user adoption is outlined as an important and unique measure of same which i also agree that it is key.

f6_assessments.q0: I think the proposal could provide more information on its solution as I do not see the need to generate invoices to be sent to payers. First of all, ADA handlers have already provided an easy way to make transactions by using the handle names of the recipient besides copy pasting addresses. Also, there is a one-click solution where addresses are automatically copied and shortcuts to auto-paste. With the insufficient information provided, I do not see the innovative idea behind this proposal.
f6_assessments.q1: The budget breakdown lacks clarity in terms of its development. For example, within month 1, the proposer could state deliverables that will be developed and the cost for required experience to do so. The roadmap and plan are not detailed, thus there's no way of understanding its development process and progress. The proposer have also not provided any social links of the team, or any other hiring team members needed for the project. With the website given, there's much work in terms of its branding, marketing and also user experience if the proposer wants the project to succeed. Which I think it needs more funding than the required budget.
f6_assessments.q2: The information provided is insufficient to audit the progress and the success of the proposal. The proposal does not indicate KPIs such as number of generated invoices, what platform to track and update the progress of the project and having constant feedback from users, and the number of errors that have occureed during generating an invoice, etc. As stated, contact with the team members could be made would be useful to measure the progress, such as Discord servers or LinkedIn links. Overall, the proposal is difficult to be auditable through all the information provided, and will be hard to evaluate its process and results based on the presented information.
